tier_0_classification.classification_reasoning: This is a numerical problem involving setting up and solving a system of equations to find the work rate of men and women, then calculating the number of men needed. It requires multiple steps to solve, making it a medium difficulty problem.

answer_validation.reasoning: Let the work rate of one man be m (bridge/week) and that of one woman be w (bridge/week). From the first condition: (1200 m + 500 w) \times 2 = 1, so 2400 m + 1000 w = 1. From the second: (900 m + 250 w) \times 3 = 1, so 2700 m + 750 w = 1. Solving these two linear equations gives m = 1/3600 bridge per week per man. To build one bridge in one week, required number of men N satisfies N m = 1, so N = 1/m = 3600. This matches option C.

step_by_step: Step 1: Assume work rates. Let one man build m bridges per week and one woman build w bridges per week.
Step 2: Use the first condition. 1200 men and 500 women complete 1 bridge in 2 weeks: (1200 m + 500 w) \times 2 = 1, giving 2400 m + 1000 w = 1.
Step 3: Use the second condition. 900 men and 250 women complete 1 bridge in 3 weeks: (900 m + 250 w) \times 3 = 1, giving 2700 m + 750 w = 1.

Step 4: Solve the simultaneous linear equations 2400 m + 1000 w = 1 and 2700 m + 750 w = 1. Subtract the first from the second: (2700-2400)m + (750-1000)w = 0, so 300 m - 250 w = 0, hence m = (5/6) w.
Step 5: Substitute m = (5/6) w into 2400 m + 1000 w = 1: 2400 (5/6) w + 1000 w = 1 \Rightarrow 2000 w + 1000 w = 1 \Rightarrow 3000 w = 1, so w = 1/3000. Then m = (5/6) \times 1/3000 = 1/3600.
Step 6: For completion in 1 week using only men, let N be the number of men. Then N m = 1 bridge/week, so N = 1/m = 3600 men.
Step 7: Compare with options: 3600 corresponds to option C.

topic.name: General aptitude - work-rate and linear equations
topic.syllabus_ref: GATE AE General Aptitude -> Quantitative aptitude -> Time and work

concepts.name: Simultaneous linear equations in two variables

essential: Understanding of rate as work done per unit time
Ability to translate word problems into algebraic equations
Solving simultaneous linear equations in two unknowns
helpful: Familiarity with standard time-and-work puzzle patterns
Comfort with checking answers by back-substitution

Main Concept: requires: Understanding of rate as work done per unit time
requires: Ability to translate word problems into algebraic equations
enables: Solving multi-person work-rate problems efficiently
enables: Tackling more complex optimization and scheduling problems

difficulty_factors: Requires setting up two correct equations from text
Needs careful algebra to avoid arithmetic slips

textbook_references.author: R.S. Aggarwal
textbook_references.section: Basic problems on work and wages
textbook_references.text_snippet: The work done is the product of rate of work and time. Many problems can be solved by assuming the total work as one unit and expressing individual rates accordingly.

video_references.professor: NPTEL - General Aptitude (e.g., Prof. Ravindra Babu or similar)
video_references.topic_covered: Time and work problems using linear equations

step_by_step_solution.solution_path: Model work rates \u2192 Form linear equations \u2192 Solve for individual rates \u2192 Compute required number of men
key_insights: Treat the whole bridge as 1 unit of work to simplify equations.
The system reduces to two linear equations in two unknowns, solvable by elimination.
Once individual rate is known, required workforce for any time is straightforward.

formulas_principles.name: Work-rate-time relation
formulas_principles.conditions: Applies when rate R is constant over time t and W is total work done
formulas_principles.relevance: Core relation to convert narrative statements into algebraic equations

formulas_principles.name: Equation from first condition
formulas_principles.conditions: Bridge work normalized to 1 unit; time is 2 weeks
formulas_principles.relevance: Encodes the first given scenario into algebra

formulas_principles.name: Equation from second condition
formulas_principles.conditions: Bridge work normalized to 1 unit; time is 3 weeks
formulas_principles.relevance: Encodes the second given scenario into algebra

formulas_principles.name: Required number of men
formulas_principles.conditions: Only men employed, work normalized to 1 bridge in 1 week
formulas_principles.relevance: Used to compute the final answer once m is known

industry_examples: Planning manpower for construction projects where different worker categories have different productivities
Scheduling maintenance tasks in aircraft hangars with mixed-skill teams
specific_systems: Aircraft assembly line staffing where technicians and helpers have different work rates
real_world_applications.practical_relevance: Understanding work-rate helps in resource planning, cost estimation, and meeting project deadlines in engineering projects, including aerospace manufacturing and maintenance.

common_mistakes.mistake: Forgetting to multiply the combined rate by the total time (2 weeks or 3 weeks) when forming the equations.
common_mistakes.why_students_make_it: They focus on the number of workers and directly equate the rate expression to 1 job, overlooking the time factor.
common_mistakes.how_to_avoid: Always write Work = Rate × Time explicitly and check that time is included before equating to 1 job.
common_mistakes.consequence: Leads to wrong equations and completely incorrect final answer.

common_mistakes.mistake: Mixing up the coefficients when subtracting the two equations, causing sign or arithmetic errors.
common_mistakes.why_students_make_it: Rushing through elimination without aligning terms carefully.
common_mistakes.how_to_avoid: Write equations one under the other, align m and w terms, and subtract slowly, checking each coefficient.
common_mistakes.consequence: Yields incorrect values for m and w, so the required number of men is wrong.

common_mistakes.mistake: After finding m, forgetting that the question asks for number of men for 1 week and not for 2 or 3 weeks.
common_mistakes.why_students_make_it: They stay mentally anchored to the original time durations and do not re-read the final question.
common_mistakes.how_to_avoid: Underline the final requirement in the question and re-check units (here, bridge/week) before computing N.
common_mistakes.consequence: May compute men needed for 2 or 3 weeks instead of 1 week, giving an answer off by a factor.

mnemonics_memory_aids.mnemonic: W = R × T: Work equals Rate times Time
mnemonics_memory_aids.concept: Basic relation connecting work, rate, and time in time-and-work problems
mnemonics_memory_aids.context: Use whenever translating a word problem about jobs or tasks into equations.

mnemonics_memory_aids.concept: Normalizing total work to 1 unit to simplify equations
mnemonics_memory_aids.context: Helps in setting up equations for any single-task completion problem.

flashcards.front: In time-and-work problems, what is the standard relation between work, rate, and time?
flashcards.back: The relation is W = R × T, where W is total work, R is rate of work, and T is time.

flashcards.front: 120 workers finish a job in 5 days. What is their combined work rate in jobs per day?
flashcards.back: Total work = 1 job. Rate = Work / Time = 1/5 job per day for all 120 workers together.

flashcards.front: If one man does m jobs/week and one woman does w jobs/week, write the equation for 1200 men and 500 women finishing 1 job in 2 weeks.
flashcards.back: Combined rate = 1200m + 500w jobs/week. Work = Rate × Time: (1200m + 500w) × 2 = 1.

flashcards.front: What is a common mistake when forming equations from time-and-work word problems?
flashcards.back: A common mistake is forgetting to multiply the combined rate by the time before equating to 1 job, leading to incorrect equations.

flashcards.front: You find one man’s rate is 1/3600 bridge/week. How many men are needed to build 1 bridge in 1 week?
flashcards.back: Let N be number of men. N × (1/3600) = 1 ⇒ N = 3600 men.

real_world_context.industry_example: Estimating how many workers of different skill levels are needed to complete a hangar construction in a given deadline.
real_world_context.why_it_matters: Underestimating or overestimating workforce leads to delays or unnecessary costs, both critical in aerospace infrastructure projects.

exam_strategy.triage_tip: Scan and see it is a standard time-and-work problem with small integers and only two unknowns. Quickly set up two equations and use elimination; should be solvable in under 3 minutes.
exam_strategy.guessing_heuristic: If stuck but know that more workers and less time means roughly proportional scaling, expect an answer larger than 2400 (since 1200 men need 2 weeks), making 3600 or 3900 more plausible than 3000 or 3300.
exam_strategy.time_management: Allocate about 2–3 minutes. If equations are not set up by 1.5 minutes, mark and move on, returning later if time permits.

search_keywords: time and work problems GATE aptitude
quantitative aptitude time and work tutorial
GATE general aptitude manpower planning problems

alternative_methods.name: Unit Work and Proportional Reasoning
alternative_methods.description: Assume the total work is 1 unit. Express the total work done in each scenario as (number of workers × time) in 'man-weeks' and 'woman-weeks'. Use proportional reasoning to relate man and woman efficiencies, then scale to 1 week.
alternative_methods.pros_cons: Pros: Builds intuition about relative efficiencies; can be faster for some. Cons: Still effectively uses the same algebra; if not structured, may confuse beginners.
alternative_methods.when_to_use: Useful when you are comfortable thinking in terms of equivalent man-weeks and want to avoid writing explicit variables for rates.

connections_to_other_subjects.Engineering Management: Similar concepts are used in project scheduling, resource allocation, and PERT/CPM analysis.
connections_to_other_subjects.Operations Research: Work-rate and resource allocation problems relate to linear programming and optimization.
connections_to_other_subjects.Flight Mechanics: Though not directly, similar rate-time reasoning appears in fuel consumption and range/endurance calculations.

deeper_dive_topics: Optimization of workforce under cost and time constraints
Introduction to linear programming for resource allocation
PERT/CPM methods for complex project scheduling

syllabus_mapping.feedback_for_syllabus_design: Well-aligned with the general aptitude component; tests basic algebra and word-problem translation skills without domain-specific aerospace knowledge.

rag_quality.notes: RAG context focused on aerodynamics, gas dynamics, structures, performance, and propulsion examples, which are unrelated to this general aptitude time-and-work problem. Solution relied entirely on internal quantitative reasoning knowledge.

future_questions_potential: Vary the composition of workers (e.g., skilled, semi-skilled, unskilled) and ask for minimum cost to complete in a given time.
Introduce overtime or variable productivity with time and ask for optimal scheduling.
Ask for fraction of work completed when workforce changes mid-way through the project.
Combine time-and-work with simple probability, e.g., chance of delays affecting completion time.

response_json.subject: General Aptitude
response_json.question_text: 1200 men and 500 women can build a bridge in 2 weeks. 900 men and 250 women will take 3 weeks to build the same bridge. How many men will be needed to build the bridge in one week?
